content.description:
A fun new favorite way up in to The Wedge, it climbs from the lowest point of the wall, up onto and across the Officer's Club Ledge, and on up to Not So Grassy Ledge.

Can be climbed in one, two, or three pitches, I'll describe it in the two pitches I recommend.

The route begins at the lowest point of the wall, just above where the approach trail first comes nearest the wall, see the beta photo and watch for the starting 8' tall broken hand crack.

One #1 and one #2 size Camalots recommended, usable on each pitch.

Pitch One: 40' 5.8

Jam the crack (a wrap or two of tape is your friend, left hand), chimney/stem above, passing two bolts above onto the ledge, two belay bolts.

Pitch Two: 60' to Officer's Club 5.10b, or 135' on to Not So Grassy Ledge 5.6

Climb the 3 bolts visible above the belay (.10b) onto the nice ledge stance (it makes for a nice location to short haul each others packs up onto the stance, leave hers clipped to the #2, and take off with mine). Continue up the hand crack for 30' and onto the 3rd class ledge system of The Officer's Club.

A row of boulders above should make you step right to get around behind them.

A bolted wide crack in white rock climbs above the boulder belay and into the second pitch of Supply Line (5.6), finishing on Not So Grassy Ledge.
content.protection: One #1 and one #2 size Camalots recommended, usable on each pitch.

climbs.name: Walter Cat
climbs.fa: Randy Leavitt, Glen Svenson, Jorge Visser, and Lauren Lee

content.description: Scramble up grassy ledges to gain the belay. From here, a low juggy flake feature tappers off into a thin seam, offering a few occasional sidepulls and shallow fingers. Follow a tricky sequence up the seam to a rail out right. Finish on thin edges to a slopey top out. A remarkably sustained and thought provoking route, especially given its (very) modest length. Enjoyable as a single pitch at the end of the day, or an alternative start to The Commander.
content.protection: 6 bolts to chains at Commander belay ledge. A lone belay bolt is at the base of the climb.
content.location: Just left of the first pitch of The Commander.

climbs.name: Huggy Bear
climbs.fa: Brian Spiewak, Randy Leavitt, and Glen Svenson

content.description: Easy first 2 bolts to a awkward bulge followed by aÂ fun bouldery move to a ledge and 3rd bolt. Then straight up the arete to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.protection: 3 bolts, 2 bolt anchor, or continue up to rap rings on nearby routes.

content.description:
A fast, fun way, far up into the heart of the wall. Finishing on the

Center Block arete pitch

of The Diamond of San Diego is spectacular and sets you up well to crag the Headwall.
content.protection:
~12 bolts. A long draw or runner here and there. Optional 3" cam on the 2nd pitch. One or two small/medium cams if you opt for the 5.9

Center Direct

start.
content.location:
Use the

Center Direct beta

to get into the corner system in the center of The Wedge.

Scramble up to the Command Center start ledge and belay off bolts on the right side. Link the right trending 5.6 pitches that lead to the 3rd pitch belay of Being and Nothingness.

After the initial three bolts leave this corner system to the left via an optional, extended 3" piece. Shown

here.

At about 90' you'll encounter an optional belay (bolts) below and right of the Center Block above you.

Extend or skip this belay and use the bolt up left to crank the last crux onto the bolted stance on the far right side of the Command Center Ledge (which is the Diamond of San Diego belay).

But don't stop here, continue on up the arete, enjoying the exposure, rock quality, and comfort of the ledge atop the Center Block
